question: Ann has 2 apples, Mark has 5 apples. How many apples do they have? Solve the equation x + y = 4, if y = 5.

A craft store makes a third of its sales in the fabric section, a quarter of its sales in the jewelry section, and the rest in the stationery section. They made 36 sales today. How many sales were in the stationery section? Ann and Bob could fill the swimming pool in 3 hours, Ann alone can fill the swimming pool in 5 hours. What time will Bob need to fill the swimmig pool by himself?

The numbers at the vertices of the cube are: 7 zeros and one unit. In one move, you are allowed to add one unit to the numbers at the ends of any edge of the cube. Is it possible to make all the numbers equal? ​​Is it possible to make all the numbers divisible by 3? Answer 1 for "yes", 0 for "no".

N friends learned N news at the same time, and each learned one news item. They started calling each other and exchanging news. Each conversation lasts 1 hour. One can share as much news as he wants during one conversation. What is the minimum number of hours needed for everyone to learn all the news? Consider three cases: a) N = 64, b) N = 55, c) N = 100.

Are there 1998 different natural numbers such that the product of every two of them is divisible by the square of their difference? On each cell of an 8×8 chessboard, a guard is placed. Each guard can look in one of four directions (along the lines of the board) and guards all the guards in the line of their sight. What is the largest k such that the guards can be directed in such a way that each guard is guarded by at least k other guards? Answer 1 for "yes", 0 for "no".

A magician and an assistant have a deck of cards; one side ("back") of all the cards is the same, while the other side is colored in one of 2017 colors (the deck contains 1,000,000 cards of each color). The magician and the assistant are going to perform the following trick. The magician leaves the room, and the audience lays out a row of  k > 1 cards face down on the table. The assistant looks at these cards, then flips all but one of them face up, without changing their order. The magician then enters the room, looks at the table, points to one of the face-down cards, and announces its color. What is the smallest k such that the magician and the assistant can agree in advance on a strategy that guarantees the trick will succeed?

a) In an infinite sequence of paper rectangles, the area of the $n$-th rectangle is equal to $n^2$. Is it always possible to cover the plane with them? Overlapping is allowed. b) Given an infinite sequence of paper squares. Is it always possible to cover the plane with them (overlapping is allowed) if it is known that for any number $N$, there exist squares whose total area is greater than $N$? Answer 1 for "yes", 0 for "no".

A numismatist has 100 coins that are identical in appearance. He knows that among them, 30 are genuine and 70 are counterfeit. Additionally, he knows that all genuine coins have the same mass, while all counterfeit coins have different masses, and each counterfeit coin is heavier than a genuine one; however, the exact masses of the coins are unknown. He has a balance scale without weights, on which he can compare the masses of two groups consisting of the same number of coins in one weighing. What is the minimum number of weighings required for the numismatist to guarantee finding at least one genuine coin?
48 blacksmiths need to shoe 60 horses. Each blacksmith spends 5 minutes on one horseshoe. What is the minimum time they must spend on the work? (Note: A horse cannot stand on two legs.)

At the beginning of the year, n pairwise unfamiliar schoolchildren joined a hypergraph enthusiasts club. Over the year, the club held 100 meetings, and each meeting was attended by at least one schoolchild. Two schoolchildren became acquainted if there was at least one meeting that both attended. At the end of the year, it turned out that the number of acquaintances each schoolchild had was no less than the number of meetings they attended. Find the minimal value of n for which this could happen.

Two people are dividing a piece of cheese. First, the first player cuts the cheese into two pieces. Then, the second player cuts any one of the existing pieces into two, and so on, until there are five pieces. After that, the first player takes one piece, then the second player takes one of the remaining pieces, then the first player again, and so on, until all pieces are taken. For each player, determine the largest amount of cheese they can guarantee for themselves.

On an island, there are 100 knights and 100 liars. Each of them has at least one friend. One day, exactly 100 people said, "All my friends are knights," and exactly 100 people said, "All my friends are liars." What is the minimal possible number of pairs of friends where one is a knight and the other is a liar?

In the center of each cell of a grid rectangle M, there is a point light bulb, initially all turned off. In one move, it is allowed to draw any straight line that does not touch the bulbs and turn on all the bulbs on one side of this line, provided all of them are currently off. Each move must turn on at least one bulb. The goal is to turn on all the bulbs while making as many moves as possible. What is the maximum number of moves that can be made if: a) M is a 21×21 square; b) M is a 20×21 rectangle?

On a board, the numbers 2, 3, 4, ..., 29, 30 are written. For one ruble, you can mark any number. If a number is already marked, you can mark its divisors and multiples for free. What is the minimal number of rubles required to mark all the numbers on the board?

A hostess baked a pie for her guests. Either 10 or 11 people may come. What is the minimal number of pieces she needs to cut the pie into in advance so that it can be divided equally among either 10 or 11 guests?

On an exam, there are three trigonometry problems, two algebra problems, and five geometry problems. Vanya solves trigonometry problems with probability $p_1 = 0.2$, geometry problems with probability $p_2 = 0.4$, and algebra problems with probability  $p_3 = 0.5$. To get a grade of 3 (pass), Vanya needs to solve at least five problems. a) What is the probability that Vanya will solve at least five problems? Vanya decides to intensively study problems from one section. In a week, he can increase the probability of solving problems from that section by 0.2. b) Which section should Vanya focus on to maximize the probability of solving at least five problems? c) Which section should Vanya focus on to maximize the expected number of solved problems? Answer 0 for "trigonometry", 1 for "algebra" and 2 for "geometry".
